results.title: Rambo: first blood. Part II (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Buzz Feitshans, Tri-Star Pictures and George Pan Cosmatos
results.brief_description: He’s on a mission and that’s just where he belongs! He’s told not to engage the enemy. “Just take pictures”, they say. But telling Rambo to hold back is like ordering a rattle-snake not to bite. Rambo’s dropped into the Vietnam jungle to find out if there are still any POW’s about. There are. And now Rambo’s going to get them home - on his own! Caption version only available. Rated: M

results.title: Rambo Issues 1985
results.brief_description: A current affairs style program, with panel members - including Phillip Adams and Max Teichman - discussing the political and moral implications of the film “Rambo”. Excerpts from Rambo are discussed alongside recorded interviews with a Vietnam veteran and a representative from a South American refugee organisation.

results.title: Raku: the ancient art of Japanese ceramics
results.creator_credit: Charles Cahill and G Roy Levin
results.brief_description: The raku process began in the 12th century in Japan growing out of a Zen Buddhist religious ceremony. Raku firing offers the potter many advantages over other techniques, and provides an intimacy and immediacy more deeply felt than any other ceramic process. Narrated by Ann Dumaresq.

results.title: Raku - English style
results.creator_credit: Castle Hill Brenchley, John Anderson and Robert Fournier
results.brief_description: A group of English potters demonstrate how Raku pottery is made, glazed and fired. The commentator clearly explains how the kiln is made while the potters construct one and use it.

results.title: Rajneesh: Spiritual Terrorist
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Connop and Vision Quest Films
results.brief_description: From all over the world thousands of affluent and educated seekers flock to the Rajneesh’s ashram in Poona, India. We gain access to the Rajneesh and to the exotic private and public lifestyles that have earned him headlines around the world. The documentary also provides intimate portraits of some of the disciples around Rajneesh, including a young American actor, a former CIA agent, a German princess, a young Australian and Rajneesh’s personal dentist.

results.title: Raising the standard
results.creator_credit: James Carr, World Wide, British Productivity Council and John Spencer
results.brief_description: Discusses the British standard of living and relates it to productivity and ways in which both may be improved. Reorganising of work is essential, and problems involved are shown. The most important of these is the attitude and, not infrequently, the opposition of workers. There is a greater need for tactful handling of problems on the part of management. Labor must realise that more work, which leads to increased productivity, means higher standard of living and not simply higher profits and dividends. The film concludes with a discussion on these points.

results.title: Rainshower
results.creator_credit: Edward Schuman, Dimension Films and Michael Murphy
results.brief_description: Presents without commentary the sights, sounds beauty and rhythm of rain. Shows how a rainshower affects the plants and animals on a farm, as well as the people in a community.

results.title: Rainmaking
results.creator_credit: S.T. Evans, CSIRO and Nicholas Alexander
results.brief_description: Making clouds rain has been the subject of intensive research in several countries since the mid-40’s. This study is the story of rainmaking in Australia - from the first tentative experiments with dry ice to the present, large-scale operations using silver iodide as the seeding agent. The film gives an account of the basic theory of cloud-seeding and outlines the techniques used in its practical application. Contains good aerial footage and use of instructional maps to describe cloud formation and rainfall.
